docs.abstract: Sampling the responses to Senator Cotton’s suggestion to use U.S. troops to suppress the protests and The Times’s decision to publish it.
docs.snippet: Sampling the responses to Senator Cotton’s suggestion to use U.S. troops to suppress the protests and The Times’s decision to publish it.

headline.main: Outcry Over Tom Cotton’s Call for Troops to Quell Unrest
headline.print_headline: Tom Cotton’s Op-Ed, and the Decision to Run It

docs.abstract: Supporters waiting to attend President Trump’s return to the campaign trail displayed their loyalty to him, though there were empty seats as the program started.
docs.snippet: Supporters waiting to attend President Trump’s return to the campaign trail displayed their loyalty to him, though there were empty seats as the program started.
docs.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — Public health experts issued dire warnings. Local officials expressed unease. The coronavirus cases continued to climb.

headline.main: Waiting for Trump: Hats, Flags, Little Fear of the Virus
headline.print_headline: Ardent Supporters Turn Out for Trump, Regardless of Virus Risk

byline.original: By Katie Glueck and Astead W. Herndon

docs.abstract: Activists set out to show that police brutality was pervasive. The police have now made that clear.
docs.snippet: Activists set out to show that police brutality was pervasive. The police have now made that clear.
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s wondrous, isn’t it, how the people just keep coming out? Day after day, night after night, in dozens of cities, braving a deadly virus and brutal retaliation, they continue to pack the streets in uncountable numbers, demanding equality and justice — and, finally, prompting what feels like real change.

docs.abstract: The post by a longtime department chairman, saying monuments should be protected from “zealots,” prompted staff charges that the museum fosters “a culture of systemic racism.”
docs.snippet: The post by a longtime department chairman, saying monuments should be protected from “zealots,” prompted staff charges that the museum fosters “a culture of systemic racism.”
docs.lead_paragraph: The turmoil coursing through cultural institutions around the country on the subject of race has made its way to the biggest museum of them all: the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline.main: Upheaval Over Race Reaches Met Museum After Curator’s Instagram Post
headline.print_headline: Met Museum Is Grappling With Protests

docs.abstract: Tazewell Thompson’s libretto for “Blue” tells the story of a black family struck by tragedy.
docs.snippet: Tazewell Thompson’s libretto for “Blue” tells the story of a black family struck by tragedy.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the opera “Blue” had its premiere last summer at the Glimmerglass Festival in Cooperstown, N.Y., Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times that it featured “one of the most elegant librettos I’ve heard in a long time.”

headline.main: My Journey to Writing an Opera About Police Violence

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Music Critics Assn of North America

docs.abstract: In the wake of George Floyd’s killing, some cities are asking if the police are being asked to do jobs they were never intended to do. Budgets are being re-evaluated.
docs.snippet: In the wake of George Floyd’s killing, some cities are asking if the police are being asked to do jobs they were never intended to do. Budgets are being re-evaluated.
docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a week of protests against police brutality and unrest that left parts of the city burned, a growing chorus of elected officials, civic leaders and residents in Minneapolis are urging the city to break up the Police Department and reimagine the way policing works.

headline.main: Cities Ask if It’s Time to Defund Police and ‘Reimagine’ Public Safety
headline.print_headline: Cities Are Questioning If It’s Time to Rethink  Structure of Policing

byline.original: By Farah Stockman and John Eligon

docs.abstract: Even as major chains boarded up stores and halted operations, they largely sought to convey empathy for demonstrators and did not condemn the damage to their businesses.
docs.snippet: Even as major chains boarded up stores and halted operations, they largely sought to convey empathy for demonstrators and did not condemn the damage to their businesses.
docs.lead_paragraph: People smashed the front doors of a Walmart in Peoria, Ill. They ransacked an Apple store in Philadelphia and broke the windows at Nordstrom’s flagship in Seattle, its hometown, while throwing merchandise into the crowds outside.

headline.main: Retailers, Battered by Pandemic, Now Confront Protests
headline.print_headline: Already Reeling, Retailers  Walk a Fine Line Amid Unrest

byline.original: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: A large Facebook parenting group temporarily shut down after silencing black members. Now new groups for parents are forming that are explicitly anti-racist.
docs.snippet: A large Facebook parenting group temporarily shut down after silencing black members. Now new groups for parents are forming that are explicitly anti-racist.
docs.lead_paragraph: A private Facebook group intended for New York City mothers has imploded over accusations of racism.

headline.main: Upper East Side Mom Group Implodes Over Accusations of Racism and Censorship

docs.abstract: Whether serious or silly, TikTok is an outlet for expression unlike anything that came before.
docs.snippet: Whether serious or silly, TikTok is an outlet for expression unlike anything that came before.
docs.lead_paragraph: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

docs.abstract: An officer replied, “I don’t care,” and the man, Derrick Scott, died shortly afterward. This week, the Oklahoma City police released recordings of the May 2019 arrest.
docs.snippet: An officer replied, “I don’t care,” and the man, Derrick Scott, died shortly afterward. This week, the Oklahoma City police released recordings of the May 2019 arrest.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma City Police Department this week released video of the arrest of a black man last year in which he can be seen pinned on the ground, saying, “I can’t breathe,” and an officer replies, “I don’t care.” The man died in custody shortly afterward.

headline.main: Video Shows Black Man Pleading ‘I Can’t Breathe’ During 2019 Arrest in Oklahoma
headline.print_headline: Video Reveals ‘Breathe’ Plea During Arrest Of Black Man

byline.original: By Mihir Zaveri and Alan Yuhas
